awd_titl_txt: Antarctic Submarine Melt Variability from Remote Sensing of Icebergs
awd_abstract_narration:
Enderlin/1643455

This award supports a project that will use a novel remote sensing method, which was initially developed to investigate melting of icebergs around Greenland, to examine spatial and temporal variations in ocean forcing around the Antarctic ice sheet periphery.  Nearly three-quarters of the Antarctic ice sheet is fringed by regions of floating glacier ice called ice shelves. These ice shelves play an important role in modulating the flow of ice from the ice sheet interior towards the coast, similar to how dams regulate the downstream flow of water from reservoirs. Therefore, a reduction in ice shelf size due to changing air and ocean temperatures can have serious implications for the flux of glacier ice reaching the Antarctic coast, and thus, sea level change. Observations of recent ocean warming in the Amundsen Sea, thinning of the ice shelves, and increased ice flux from the West Antarctic ice sheet interior suggests that ice shelf destabilization triggered by ocean warming may already be underway in some regions. Although detailed observations are available in the Amundsen Sea region, our understanding of spatial and temporal variations in ocean conditions and their influence on ice shelf stability is limited by the scarceness of observations spanning the ice sheet periphery. The project will yield insights into variability in the submarine melting of ice shelves and will help advance the career of a female early-career scientist in a male-dominated field.

The project will use repeat, very high-resolution (~0.5 m pixel width and length) satellite images acquired by the WorldView satellites, to estimate rates of iceberg melting in key coastal regions around Antarctica. The satellite images will be used to construct maps of iceberg surface elevation, which will be differenced in time to derive time series of iceberg volume change and area-averaged melt rates. Where ocean data are available, the melt rates will be compared to these data to assess whether variations in ocean temperature can explain observed iceberg melt variability. Large spatial gradients in melt rates will be compared to estimates of iceberg drift rates, which will be inferred from the repeat satellite images as well as numerically modeled drift rates produced by (unfunded) collaborators, to quantify the effects of water shear on iceberg melt rates. Spatial and temporal patterns in iceberg melting will also be compared to independently derived ice shelf thickness datasets. Overall, the analysis should yield insights into the effects of changes in ocean forcing on the submarine melting of Antarctic ice shelves and icebergs. The project does not require field work in Antarctica.

por.por_cntn:
The overall goal of this project was to map iceberg melt rates around Antarctica using satellite images and determine whether variations in iceberg melt rates in space or time can be used to infer changing ocean conditions along Antarctica?s frozen margins. We estimated melt rates for hundreds of icebergs from 15 sites around Antarctica (see map figure) using iceberg surface elevations from satellite observations collected between 2012-2021. Rates of ice loss from marine glacier margins and iceberg melt rates vary together around the Antarctic Peninsula, suggesting that variations in ocean conditions strongly influence iceberg melting from and submarine melting of glaciers.

 

Along the eastern Antarctic Peninsula, where the rates of iceberg melting and ice loss from marine-terminating glaciers is small, some glacier termini are advancing into the ocean.  Focusing on Crane Glacier, which flowed into the Larsen B Ice Shelf prior to its collapse in 2022, we used a numerical ice flow model to test whether ocean temperatures are so cold that submarine melting of the glacier margin has minimal influence on glacier flow and mass change over time. Our model results suggest that the glacier will maintain a nearly constant flux towards the ocean throughout the 21st century even if there is a moderate increase in surface melting and/or submarine melting due to climate warming. The relative insensitivity of the glacier to future climate forcing following ice shelf loss is interesting because the glacier losses much of its floating ice tongue in the majority of the climate forcing simulations. Based on these results we expect that mass loss from the glaciers that formerly flowed into the Larsen A and B Ice Shelves will be relatively modest in the coming decades, even if the recent pattern of terminus retreat is reversed.

 

We also found that variations in iceberg melt rates around Antarctica cannot be entirely explained by regional variations in ocean temperature. There is no consistent relationship between iceberg melt rate and far-field ocean temperature across all study sites, likely reflecting the influence of glacier and iceberg meltwater on local water properties. Local water modification is particularly obvious where melt rates appear to be enhanced by plumes of fresh water emanating from beneath the glaciers. The discrepancy between observed iceberg melt rates and expected melt rates based on far-field ocean observations or models is important because it indicates that we cannot rely on regional ocean observations to infer changes in ocean properties at the margins of Antarctica?s glaciers and ice shelves. As such, the results of the project are important for both the glaciology and oceanography communities.

 

In addition to the creation of a novel iceberg melt rate dataset and the results of the observational and modeling studies described above, this project had important impacts on the professional development of the lead investigator and a diverse array of students involved in the project. This was the lead investigator?s first project focused on Antarctica and it provided her with the opportunity to broaden the geographic scope of her group?s research and foster collaborative relationships with new colleagues. The project funded two Masters thesis projects and research conducted by three undergraduate researchers. The majority of the students involved in the project are from under-represented groups in the physical sciences. As such, the project helped increase diversity in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) workforce. The students all learned valuable technical skills, such as scientific programming and data management, as well as highly transferrable ?soft? skills. The students were all given opportunities to hone their oral, visual, and written scientific communication skills and learned how to work in a collaborative interdisciplinary environment. The project funded the education and research of the Masters students and research conducted by the undergraduates, thus providing them with opportunities that they would not obtain from classroom instruction alone.
